transcript:
Computer Science > Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition
[Submitted on 7 Dec 2023]
Digital Life Project: Autonomous 3D Characters with Social Intelligence
Zhongang Cai, Jianping Jiang, Zhongfei Qing, Xinying Guo, Mingyuan Zhang, Zhengyu Lin, Haiyi Mei, Chen Wei, Ruisi Wang, Wanqi Yin, Xiangyu Fan, Han Du, Liang Pan, Peng Gao, Zhitao Yang, Yang Gao, Jiaqi Li, Tianxiang Ren, Yukun Wei, Xiaogang Wang, Chen Change Loy, Lei Yang, Ziwei Liu
In this work, we present Digital Life Project, a framework utilizing language as the universal medium to build autonomous 3D characters, who are capable of engaging in social interactions and expressing with articulated body motions, thereby simulating life in a digital environment. Our framework comprises two primary components: 1) SocioMind: a meticulously crafted digital brain that models personalities with systematic few-shot exemplars, incorporates a reflection process based on psychology principles, and emulates autonomy by initiating dialogue topics; 2) MoMat-MoGen: a text-driven motion synthesis paradigm for controlling the character's digital body. It integrates motion matching, a proven industry technique to ensure motion quality, with cutting-edge advancements in motion generation for diversity. Extensive experiments demonstrate that each module achieves state-of-the-art performance in its respective domain. Collectively, they enable virtual characters to initiate and sustain dialogues autonomously, while evolving their socio-psychological states. Concurrently, these characters can perform contextually relevant bodily movements. Additionally, a motion captioning module further allows the virtual character to recognize and appropriately respond to human players' actions. Homepage: this https URL

key_facts: Digital Life Project is a framework for building autonomous 3D characters using language as a universal medium.
The framework enables 3D characters to engage in social interactions and express through body motions.
SocioMind is the digital brain component that models personalities with few-shot exemplars.
SocioMind incorporates a reflection process based on psychology principles.
SocioMind enables autonomy by allowing characters to initiate dialogue topics.
MoMat-MoGen is a text-driven motion synthesis paradigm for controlling character bodies.
MoMat-MoGen integrates motion matching for high-quality motion output.
MoMat-MoGen combines motion matching with cutting-edge motion generation for diversity.
Experiments show both SocioMind and MoMat-MoGen achieve state-of-the-art performance.
Characters can autonomously initiate and sustain dialogues while evolving socio-psychological states.
Characters perform contextually relevant bodily movements in response to interactions.
A motion captioning module allows characters to recognize and respond to human players' actions.
The project was submitted on December 7, 2023, under arXiv:2312.04547 [cs.CV].
The paper is categorized under Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (cs.CV).
Additional subject areas include Artificial Intelligence (cs.AI), Graphics (cs.GR), and Human-Computer Interaction (cs.HC).
The authors are affiliated with multiple institutions including Tsinghua University and Alibaba Group.
The framework simulates life in a digital environment through autonomous behavior.
Language serves as the primary interface for interaction between characters and users.
SocioMind uses systematic few-shot exemplars to model personality traits.
The reflection process in SocioMind is grounded in psychological theories.
Autonomous dialogue initiation is enabled by SocioMind's internal decision-making logic.
Motion matching ensures realistic and natural-looking character movements.
Motion generation advances contribute to diverse and expressive motion sequences.
The system supports continuous evolution of character emotional and social states.
Human players can influence character behavior via physical actions recognized by the motion captioning module.
key_opinions: The integration of psychology-based reflection enhances the realism of virtual characters.
Using language as a universal medium is a promising approach for scalable character design.
The combination of motion matching and generative methods strikes an optimal balance between quality and diversity.
SocioMind’s ability to initiate conversations makes characters feel more lifelike and proactive.
The motion captioning module significantly improves interactivity with human users.
This framework represents a major leap toward truly autonomous digital beings.
The project demonstrates strong potential for applications in gaming and virtual assistants.
Future work should focus on long-term memory and relationship dynamics between characters.
The use of few-shot exemplars reduces dependency on large training datasets.
The modular design allows for independent improvement of each component.
